name: Air_Travel.xlsx
data: Gartner has negotiated preferred (primary) contracts with certain airlines. Agents will offer the lowest logical fare, including web fares and regional carrier fares with consideration given to our preferred carriers. Gartner's preferred airlines should be used whenever they reasonably match your itinerary requirements and are reasonably close to the lowest market price.

The policy states (i) should provide a link or reference to the preferred suppliers.The travel policy identifies any preferred carriers by name & include a requirement for travelers to utilize them whenever appropriate scheduling and routing is available.

All associates are required to book every business trip via the TMC in one of three ways (no exceptions): 1) by phone with a travel counselor 2) by email with a travel counselor, or 3) online with an authorized online booking tool in regions where this is available.

The policy states; (i) Travelers will be advised to use the preferred air carriers and to book all reservations through the designated travel agency and/or on-line booking tool; (ii) mandating this reservation method is a best practice.

ONLY these published authorized methods for booking business travel are to be used. Associates are specifically prohibited from going directly to airline carrier websites or the internet to purchase airline tickets.

The policy indicates (i)  the preferred method of payment for air travel expenses if it differs to the instruction in the general travel arrangements or expence management. Alternatively refers to that (link/section/area).
Lowest Logical Airfare, including airline search windows

Lowest logical fares for itineraries offered by the TMC or Gartner's online booking tool providers should be the primary selection criteria. TMC Agents have been tasked with searching for flights three (3) hours prior to the requested departure and three (3) hours later than the requested return in order to search for the lowest fares.

A lowest logical fare policy ensures maximum use of discounted fares for those travelers required to fly Economy Class. (i) The policy will include considerations such as time window, number of connections, alternate airports, potential savings, and preferred vendors; (ii) mandating the use of LLA is a best practice.

Advanced purchase of airline tickets increases the likelihood of a lower fare; therefore, flights should be purchased at least 14 days prior to departure to take advantage of significant cost-savings.
(i) The policy encourages booking travel as far in advance as possible; (ii) mandating this requirement and indicating a minimum number of days prior to travel is a best practice.

All air travel for any segment less than 8 hours in length will be ticketed at the lowest logical fare, which generally means non-refundable, coach or economy class seats. Associates are eligible to fly business class only if the in-flight continuous time exceeds 8 hours per segment OR if total flight time exceeds 10 hours without an overnight stay.

The policy states (i) Indicate the approved cabin class based on destination/distance/time; a best practice is indicated if (ii) Economy is the appropriate cabin class for short duration flights with Premium or Business class permissible if the flight exceeds a specified number of hours/distance (not less than four hours).(iii) specify if cabin class usage differs for Domestic, Regional or Intercontinental flights.

NON-REFUNDABLE, RESTRICTED TICKETS should be used. Non-refundable tickets are generally significantly less expensive. In case of a change to your travel plans, most non-refundable tickets can be exchanged for a fee.
(i) The policy encourages the use of non-refundable or penalty tickets; (ii) mandating their use whenever possible is a best practice.

Travelers are responsible for cancelling air reservations by using the same method as their booking procedures. If the TMC office is closed, please call the after-hours number provided on your itinerary.

The policy states (i) The employee is advised to contact the designated travel agency to cancel air travel reservations, or cancel the reservations in whatever manner the reservations were originally booked.

If you cancel a ticketed trip prior to the date of departure, you are likely eligible for a credit of the fare of the unused ticket, though restrictions will apply. Please work with the TMC to see if you have unused tickets available to use towards a future trip on the exact same carrier.
(i) The policy indicates that travelers will contact the agency/travel department regarding unused electronic tickets/Paper Tickets for refund.

Airlines occasionally offer free tickets or cash allowances to compensate travelers for delays and inconvenience due to overbooking, flight cancellation, changes of equipment etc. Travelers may volunteer for denied boarding compensation only if the delay will not cause an increase in trip cost AND will not result in any interruption or loss of business.

The policy indicates (i)  whether employee is permitted to volunteer for denied boarding compensation and if permitted, that corporate timelines/commitments should not be compromised in any way; (ii) expenses related thereto should not be reimbursable.
Premium seat assignment charges are not reimbursable.

(i) The policy states whether payment for preferred seating (i.e. aisle window or emergency exit seat in designated rows of an aircraft are allowed if any fees for such seating are reimbursable and the applicable form of payment (i.e. corp. credit card- cash etc.).

Baggage charges are reimbursable if necessary to conduct business. The company will reimburse associates for the first piece of luggage. Second bag charge only reimbursed if trip over 10 days or required for company material.
The policy states: (i) Guidelines for spending must be provided but generally, not a reimbursable expense unless required for transport of business-related materials.
Airline Internet Fees (GoGo, Fly-Fi, Row 44, T-Mobile, OnAir, Panasonic Avionics, etc.) which exceed $20 per flight are not reimbursable.

(i) As wireless service become available on aircraft, the policy will advise if the traveler can utilize these services, (ii) if these fees are reimbursable and the applicable form of payment (i.e. corp. credit card, cash, etc.).
All luggage charges must be paid for using the company corporate card. Excess baggage or luggage weight overages will not be reimbursed unless it was material or equipment necessary for business.

(i) The policy should state whether checking a first or second piece of luggage (based on airline) is allowed and under what circumstances, (ii) since the airlines charge a fee for this, if it is reimbursable, and the applicable form of payment (i.e. corp. credit card, cash, etc.).

(I) If an overnight delay should occur, the policy will instruct the traveler to contact the designated travel agency immediately to assist with hotel accommodations or attempt to obtain complimentary accommodations from the air carrier.  The Company will indicate that reasonable expenses are reimbursable, if beyond the employee's control.

Rating is Null Because: Policy does not address overnight delay procedures and accommodationsContent: Policy should include guidance on overnight delays including contacting TMC for hotel accommodations, seeking complimentary accommodations from airlines, and reimbursement of reasonable expenses beyond employee control.

AIRLINE UPGRADES are NOT reimbursable. They are considered a personal expense and cannot be charged on the corporate credit card, nor should they be expensed as a business expense. Under no circumstances shall associates be permitted to book a higher unrestricted fare to qualify for an upgrade.
The policy states: (i) Upgrading an existing tickets to a class upgrade to Premium (Purchased).  (ii) Any additional charges are the responsibility of the employee.
In Flight Meal Fees and Alcoholic Beverages
(i)Reimbursable as part of meal allowance or per diem.

Rating is Null Because: Policy does not address in-flight meal fees and alcoholic beveragesContent: Policy should specify if in-flight meals and alcoholic beverages are reimbursable as part of meal allowance or per diem.
Airline Rewards and Frequent Flyer Programs

FREQUENT FLYER PROGRAMS are considered a personal benefit. You may retain any mileage accumulated for an airline as a result of business travel to be used for personal travel. Using your personal credit card to pay for airfare or allowing airline miles to influence your flight selection is strictly prohibited.

(i) The policy indicates whether the employee is permitted to retain the benefits of these programs for personal use; however, the policy indicates that (ii) under no circumstances may a higher priced flight or alternate carrier be selected on the basis of participation in one of these programs; (iii) the policy also states that membership fees associated with joining these programs are not reimbursable.
AIRLINE CLUB MEMBERSHIPS within the airports are considered personal expenses by the IRS and will not be reimbursed by the company worldwide.
(i) The policy should indicate if airline club memberships are reimbursable; generally they are not considered reimbursable.

If the airfare on a non-preferred airline vs. a preferred airline results in a savings of $100 or more round trip for domestic flights and $400 or more round trip for international flights you may choose to use the non-preferred airline.
Threshold should be provided for Ticket Rates.

PARKING FEES Parking fees for your personal car or rental car will be reimbursed when traveling to business meetings or to your local area airport for business purposes. You should inquire about corporate rates at airport parking facilities. If your trip is longer than a week, long term parking should be used.

The policy indicates (i) spending guidelines for airport parking while traveling on business and the circumstances under which the parking fees are reimbursable; (ii) the policy should prohibit use of high cost short term on-site airport parking facilities.
ADDITIONAL FLIGHT INSURANCE AND PERSONAL TRAVEL INSURANCE is not considered business expenses and, therefore, is not reimbursable.

The policy states: (i) Costs for additional premiums should not be reimbursable.  (ii) The policy indicates the extent of coverage provided by use of the corporate card, if available, or through other company-sponsored sources.

LOST OR STOLEN LUGGAGE (including cash) and the cost to replace personal items are the sole responsibility of the traveler. Most airlines will pay for checked lost baggage; all claim checks should be kept to assist in these situations.

The policy states:  Employees are to be directed to report any baggage loss to the air carrier immediately; (i) premiums for baggage insurance are not reimbursable as coverage is typically available with the use of a corporate-sponsored credit card.  (ii) Extent of coverage must be detailed in the policy.
